Example

Write the following as a simple power with a single index.

  1. \(\sqrt{x^5}\)
  2. \(\sqrt[4]{x^3}\)

Solution

  1. \(\sqrt{x^5} = (x^5)^{\frac{1}{2}}\). Then using the third law of indices we can write this as \(x^{5\times{\frac{1}{2}}}=x^{\frac{5}{2}}.\)
  2. \(\sqrt[4]{x^3} =(x^3)^{\frac{1}{4}}\). Using the third law we can write this as \(x^{3\times \frac{1}{4}}=x^{\frac{3}{4}}.\)

 

Example

Show that \(z^{-\frac{1}{2}}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{z}}.\)

Solution

\(z^{-\frac{1}{2}}=\dfrac{1}{z^{\frac{1}{2}}}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{z}}.\)

 

Example

The generalisation of the third law of indices states that \((a^mb^n)^k=a^{mk}b^{nk}\). By taking \(m=1\), \(n=1\) and \(k=\dfrac{1}{2}\) show that \(\sqrt{ab}=\sqrt{a}\,\sqrt{b}\).

Solution

Taking \(m=1\), \(n=1\) and \(k=\dfrac{1}{2}\) gives

\((ab)^{\frac{1}{2}}=a^{\frac{1}{2}}b^{\frac{1}{2}}\).

Taking the case when all these roots are positive, we have

\(\sqrt{ab}=\sqrt{a}\sqrt{b}\)

 

Key Point

\(\sqrt{ab}=\sqrt{a}\sqrt{b} \qquad  a\ge 0,\ \ b\ge 0\).


This result often allows answers to be written in alternative forms. For example, we may write \(\sqrt{48}\) as \(\sqrt{3\times 16}=\sqrt{3}\sqrt{16}=4\sqrt{3}\).

Although this rule works for multiplication we should be aware that it does not work for addition or subtraction so that \(\sqrt{a\pm b}\ne \sqrt{a}\pm\sqrt{b}\).
